Because (a) I think that itâ€™s something that you want to do as a developer anyway, but (b) itâ€™ll help you get a little bit more insight and empathy into whatâ€™s going on. VoiceOver is by far not the greatest technique out there for testing stuff, but it is a technique and it will give you some fascinating insights into how some of this stuff actually works. Plus, you have to remember that a person who is using a screen reader is going to be much more proficient at using the screen reader than you are. So you have to kind of take your own downsize that you come up with, with a little bit a grain of salt. So, it is a good idea to try to find some real people with some disabilities that can test your stuff out. JOE:Â  So, what about when youâ€™re going to do a project and you do want to make it accessible? Maybe youâ€™re going to take a measured approach and not do everything, but you do want to do some stuff, but just knowing what you can do and whatâ€™s going to be achieved and whatâ€™s going to get expensive in the list of all the things you could do and need to worry about. Is there some place you can go so you can see, â€œWell, if I just do these five things, Iâ€™ve already majorly increased the accessibility of my site,â€ over what I would have been without doing anything? BRIAN:Â  Thereâ€™s a couple of resources that I typically point people to. The first one would be the site, the WebAIM site. So, thatâ€™s webaim.org and theyâ€™ve got a lot of good resources on there. But thereâ€™s also the WCAG, the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, and if you can follow those, thatâ€™s a pretty good start. Itâ€™s a pretty good checklist. But the other thing to think about is if youâ€™re building something, and this is actually where a lot of my work goes, is if youâ€™re building something for a government agency here in the US, and thatâ€™s for any agency that receives Federal dollars, really. Then thereâ€™s another thing you want to look at, which is Section508.gov, because thatâ€™s actually the Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act that covers, there was an amendment to it back in 2001 or so, that covers exactly what you must do for accessibility for these types of sites. And itâ€™s very specific. Now, Section 508 is supposed to be getting an overhaul, but it just seems to be stalling. And so, itâ€™s a bit eye-opening when you look at the types of restraints you have for working on these types of sites that receive Federal dollars. But thatâ€™s a couple of good checklist you can do when youâ€™re just trying -- you want to try, you want to start down that path. How does a person with a hearing disability participate in this podcast? CHUCK:Â  They read the transcript. BRIAN:Â  There you go. And thatâ€™s another thing to think about. And for the motor impairments, thatâ€™s the same kind of thing. We talked about the head wands, but their issue is itâ€™s harder for them to hit those targets. BRIAN:Â  Yeah, and it comes back to if we pay attention to accessibility as a whole, which means access for everybody, then we make the experience better for everybody. Another thing to think about is the color blind. People with the various types of color blindness have problems distinguishing between certain colors. And if youâ€™re trying to use color as a way to draw someoneâ€™s attention to things, itâ€™s a pretty good idea to have another way to draw attention to that also. And itâ€™s typically where the idea of, not only do we got to make the text red, but weâ€™re also going to put little asterisks. One of my favorite things is the built-in way the Rails framework handled the form validation thatâ€™s built into, when I saw the first scaffolding video. Because I thought, okay, I know a lot of developers are going to hate that because not only does it list the things that are wrong on the top and then it outlines all the fields and I know a lot of developers are going to hate that. But when I first looked at that, thatâ€™s actually how the Section 508 guidelines want you to do it. They want you to give a summary description at the top of the form of all the things the user did wrong. And then, you have to mark individual fields. BRIAN:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s the hardest uphill battle with this. This is why books on accessibility donâ€™t sell well, because people here go, â€œIâ€™m scared,â€ or, â€œItâ€™s going to be a lot of work,â€ or, â€œItâ€™s going to be too expensive,â€ and itâ€™s really not. It really comes down to empathy. Thatâ€™s really what it comes down to. Every time I talk about this at a conference or wherever, thatâ€™s what I start off with, is empathy. Letâ€™s talk about the difficulties that people have. Letâ€™s think about the difficulties they have, so that those could be in the back of our mind when we go through these things. And one of the disabilities that we donâ€™t really think about too much that does happen to cause grief for people is, the people with cognitive or learning disabilities. Is the text on your page, is it spell-checked? Is it grammatically correct? Is it easy to follow? Whatâ€™s the reading level of the text on your page or the copy? Is it easy to follow or is it full of a bunch of big superfluous words? Because you have reading comprehension issues, you have people with dyslexia. The type of font that you choose might make it harder for someone to pick out the words. And so, those are the kinds of disabilities that we donâ€™t really think about too much, but it also causes problems for people. And just by being aware of those types of things, as weâ€™re writing our copy, we might think about that, â€œOh, do I really need to use this word or can I use a simpler word to describe what Iâ€™m doing?â€ Or, â€œHey, did I spell-check this?â€ Because not only is going to make it hard for someone with dyslexia if I spell things wrong, but itâ€™s also going to make the screen readers trip over themselves when they try to interpret the words. So just thinking about those things, thatâ€™s where most of the upfront work comes from. Now, thereâ€™s, of course, going to be some technical challenges and going to be some things that youâ€™re just not going to be able to do. But any step you take is better than no steps at all. BRIAN:Â  It comes back to those things the ARIA Live roles where you can actually specify this region of the page and its children are dynamic and they will change. And so, the screen readers are supposed to be able to then subscribe to that section of the page and alert you that elements have changed in there. Now, it sounds like itâ€™s highly complicated but this is actually kind of a solved problem for other areas of the user interface. Microsoft Word, for example, is a pretty highly graphical program. One of the things thatâ€™s always kind of surprising is that thereâ€™s been this, for the last ten years or more, thereâ€™s been this push of â€˜donâ€™t use tables for layouts, donâ€™t use tables for layoutsâ€™. And one of the reasons was that itâ€™s a bad idea. The other reason was that itâ€™s an accessibility issue. AJ:Â  [Coughs] Amazon, [coughs] Amazon. BRIAN:Â  Well, I was thinking Hacker News, but thatâ€™s beside the point. The point isâ€¦ [Laughter] BRIAN:Â  The point Iâ€™m getting at here is that the screen readers have gotten good at reading tabled layouts. They donâ€™t have nearly the trouble they used to have. Now, itâ€™s still not a good idea to do them, but the screen readers have been forced to adapt to it. Theyâ€™re always playing catch up, but theyâ€™ve been forced to adapt to it. I donâ€™t think you should do that, but you can. And so, when youâ€™re thinking about where weâ€™re going with the web, I think what can happen is if we can get more developers to think about accessibility, to think about accessibility issues, then we can get things into Chrome and we can get things into WebKit, we can get things into the other browsers to build better APIs to make things more accessible for people.
